qas.question: What is the purpose of Obstruction?

answers.text: frustrating the majority party's ability to govern or attracting press and media attention to the alleged ineffectiveness
motions to adjourn, appeals of the presiding officer's ruling, or numerous requests for roll call votes

qas.question: Is it safe to employ negative strategy?
What may be a risk negative tactic?

answers.text: if his party fails to offer policy alternatives that appeal to broad segments of the general public

qas.question: Who's attention is attracted when the public forms a negative campaign?
What does the majority party do that makes the public want to respond with a negative campaign?
What was Gephardt Dilatory accused of being a part of?
What is forming policy alternatives also considered to be by the press?

plausible_answers.text: launch a campaign against a "do-nothing Congress"

qas.question: What is the public able to do on its own against policies that aren't popular?

context: A look at one minority leadership strategy—partisan opposition—may suggest why it might be employed in specific circumstances. The purposes of obstruction are several, such as <a0_0>frustrating the majority party's ability to govern or attracting <b4_0>press and media attention<b4_0/> to the <b5_0>alleged ineffectiveness<b5_0/><a0_0/> of the majority party. "We know how to delay," remarked Minority Leader Gephardt Dilatory <a1_0>motions to adjourn, appeals of the presiding officer's ruling, or numerous requests for roll call votes<a1_0/> are <b7_0>standard time-consuming parliamentary tactics<b7_0/>. By stalling action on the majority party's agenda, the minority leader may be able to <b8_0>launch a campaign against <b6_0>a "do-nothing Congress"<b8_0/><b6_0/> and convince enough voters to put his party back in charge of the House. To be sure, the minority leader recognizes that <a2_0>"going negative" carries risks<a2_0/> and may not be a winning strategy <a3_0>if his party fails to offer policy alternatives that appeal to broad segments of the general public<a3_0/>.
